titleStmt.title: Hereafter ensueth the auncient seuerall customes, of the seuerall mannors of Stebbunhuth, and Hackney, within the countie of Middlesex which were perused, viewed & approued, by the lorde of the said mannors, and by all the copieholde tenants of the said seueral mannors, manie yeeres past, and which customes be now againe newelie and fullie considered off, ratified, allowed, and approued, by the right Honourable, Henrie L. Wentworth, lord of the saide seueral mannors, as in the seuerall articles & agreements hereafter following are expressed, the x. day of Nouember. 1587. and in the 29. yeere of the raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie Elizabeth, by the grace of God, Queene of England, Fraunce and Ireland, defender of the faith.
Auncient severall customes, of the severall mannors of Stebbunhuth, and Hackney, 1587.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Hereafter en≈øueth the auncient ≈øeuerall cu≈øtomes, of the ≈øeuerall Mannors of Stebbunhuth, and Hackney,Stebbunhuth, Hackney. within the Countie of Middle≈øex, which were peru≈øed, viewed & approued, by the Lorde of the ≈øaid Mannors, and by all the Copieholde Tenants of the ≈øaid ≈øeueral Mannors, manie yeeres pa≈øt, and which cu≈øtomes be now againe newelie and fullie con≈øidered off, ratified, allowed, and approued, by the right Honorable, Henrie L. Wentworth, Lord of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall Mannors, and all the Copieholde Tenantes of the ≈øaid Mannors, as in the ≈øeuerall Articles & agreements hereafter following are expre≈ø≈øed, the x. day of Nouember. 1587. And in the 29. yeere of the raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie Elizabeth, by the grace of God, Queene of England, Fraunce and Ireland, defender of the faith.
div.p:
INprimis, by the cu≈øtomes of the ≈øaid Mannours, al the Copieholde Landes and Tenementes of the ≈øaide Mannours, and of euerie of them, be, and alwaies haue beene auncient copieholdes of inheritance in Fee≈øimple, according to the ≈øeuerall cu≈øtomes of the ≈øaide Mannours, and of euerie of them, of which the ≈øame been ≈øeuerally holden, except ≈øuth parts and parcells of the ≈øaid Mannours, or of either of them, being of the demea≈øne lands, and of the wa≈øts of the ≈øaid mannours,
and of either of them, which haue not beene graunted out by the Lorde or Lords of the ≈øame, to holde by coppie of Court roll, but ≈øithens the beginning of the raigne of the queenes Maie≈øtie that nowe is, which partes and parcells ≈øo graunted to holde by coppie of court roll. are and be excepted, and are ment to bee excepted out of the≈øe Articles, ratification and agreement, and al≈øo all other the landes, tenements, and hereditamentes, mentioned and ≈øpecified in the ≈øeconde ≈øedule to the≈øe pre≈øents annexed, which are and ≈øhalbe of no other validitie and force then they ≈øhoulde haue beene of, if the≈øe articles and agreements had neuer been made. And all coppies haue beene tyme out of minde, and bee made to holde of the Lord by the rodde, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaide mannours, by the rents, cu≈øtomes, ≈øuts and ≈øeruices, therefore due and accu≈øtomed.

2 Item, the rentes of all the tenements, both freeholders, and coppieholders, which holde anie me≈øwages, cotages, lands, tenements, or hereditaments of the ≈øaide mannours, or of anie of them is
yeerelie payable at the fea≈øt of ≈øaint Michaell Tharchangell, to the Lorde and his heires, the ≈øame to be collected by Reeues of the ≈øaid mannors, to be yeerelie cho≈øen, as heereafter is expre≈ø≈øed, and all and euerie the coppieholde Tenants, ≈øhal hereafter pay ≈øo much rent as anie of them haue paid within two yeeres la≈øt pa≈øt for their ≈øeuerall coppieholds, & that if anie one of the ≈øaide coppieholds, for the which anie intire quitrent is nowe paide, ≈øhall come into ≈øeuerall hands, the ≈øaide rent ≈øhall be apporcioned by thomage.

3 Item, all the coppieholde Tenants, which now be, or heereafter for the time being ≈øhalbe, ought to appeare yeerelie at two generall Courts holden for the ≈øaid mannors, or for either of them. And al≈øo ≈øo many of them at al other ≈øet or apointed Courts, ≈øet, appointed, or kept, or to be ≈øet, apointed, or kept, for the ≈øaid mannors, or for either of them, or for the Lord or Lords of the ≈øaid manors, or of either of them as ≈øhall be warned therevnto by the Reeue or his ≈øufficient deputy for the time being, and they to doe their ≈øutes
and ≈øeruices according to their tenures, except they be e≈ø≈øoyned, lycenced, or haue ≈øome other lawful excu≈øe, vpon the paine heereafter following, which generall courts haue beene commonlie kept, and are to be kept yeerelie thone of them the Tue≈ødaie next after Lowe Sundaye, & thother about the fea≈øt of Saint Andrewe the apo≈øtle, vpon rea≈øonable warning.

4 Item, if anie of the cu≈øtomarie or copieholde tenants of the ≈øaid Mannors, or of either of them, doe or ≈øhall make default in their appearaunce at anie of the ≈øaide two generall courts to which their ≈øutes ≈øhall be due, or if ≈øuch copieholde tenants as ≈øhallbe e≈øpeciallie warned to appeare at anie of the ≈øaide ≈øette Courts in forme afore≈øaide, yeerelie to be holden, doe make default, to which the ≈øaide ≈øute is or ≈øhalbe due, and warning openlie giuen in the pari≈øh churches within the ≈øaid Mannours, of the daie and place of the holdyng of the ≈øame generall courts, & vpon ≈øpeciall warning to be giuen for the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øet Courts, that then they that ≈øhall ≈øo make default, except
they be e≈ø≈øoyned, or haue ≈øome other lawfull or rea≈øonable excu≈øe, ≈øhall be amer≈øed by the homage of the ≈øaide Court or anie of them, which amerciement ≈øhall bee taxed by two Afferrours of the ≈øayde Court. That is to ≈øay, by two Tenants of the homage, whereof the Steward of the ≈øaide Mannours, or of either of them for the time being, hath alwaies v≈øed to choo≈øe, and ≈øhal choo≈øe one for the Lorde, and the re≈øidue of the homage then pre≈øent, haue cho≈øen, and heareafter ≈øhall choo≈øe the other.

5 Item, if anie Tenant bee Summoned to appeare at anie ≈øet Court or Courts to bee holden within the ≈øaide Mannors, or in anie of them, and doth appeare vppon the ≈øaide Sommons, he ought, and is to haue for his paines iiij. d. and his dinner, or viij. d. and no dinner, which ought and is by the ≈øaide cu≈øtome to bee paid by ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons who ≈øhall bee the cau≈øe that anie ≈øuch Tenants do appeare for his or their matter, ≈øo it bee not for any matter or cau≈øe that concerneth an inquirie or pre≈øentment to be made concerning the Lord for the time
being, his heires or a≈ø≈øignes.

6 Item, the Copieholde Tenants of the ≈øaide Mannours, and of eyther of them, ought to haue euerie of them like allowaunce vpon euerie viewe by them to bee made, and vpon euerie partition by them to be made, or vppon other Summons to appeare betwixt Tenaunt and Tenant, when they be appointed therevnto by precept from the Stewarde of the ≈øaid mannors, or of either of them for the time being, or by his ≈øufficient deputie.

7 Item, the homage of the Court of the ≈øaide Mannours, or of anie of them, may appoint ≈øixe or ≈øeuen Tenants vppon aanie complaint to them made by anie per≈øon or per≈øons being Tenantes of the ≈øaide mannours, or of either of them in open Court, that he or they be wronged by any incrochmeÃÑt, or anie other annoyaunce, which Tenauntes ≈øhall after the ≈øaide Court, viewe the ≈øame incrochment, annoyance, and impediment, or place whereof anie ≈øuch complaint ≈øhall be made, and therevpon to pre≈øent or notifie the ≈øame by a day to the Stewarde, or to the homage at the next generall
Court, that there may be ≈øette a paine or amerciement, or both, for the ≈øame, by the homage at the ≈øaide next Court, according to the qualitie of the offence.

8 Item, the homage of euerie of the ≈øaide Mannours, are to make pre≈øentment at euerie general Court to be holden for the ≈øaid Mannours, or for either of them, of all the cu≈øtomarie or coppieholde Tenauntes, that they ≈øhall knowe ≈øhall haue died, after the Court then la≈øt pa≈øt, or at any time before the ≈øaid court, who≈øe deathes were not then found and pre≈øented, which ≈øhall haue holden anie cu≈øtomarie or coppieholde Landes or Tenementes of the ≈øaid Mannours, or of either of them. And al≈øo as neere as they can, pre≈øent what Landes they dyed ≈øeazed of, and al≈øo of what e≈øtate, and when he died, and who is the next heire or heyres to the ≈øame per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øo dying ≈øeazed, and of what age or ages the ≈øaide heyre or heyres ≈øhall then bee off as neere as they can.

9 Item, likewi≈øe the homage ought to pre≈øent the deathes of freeholders, and
when they dyed, and who bee their next heyres, and the ages of their heires which helde anie Lands or Tenements of the ≈øaide mannours, or of either of them, and the nature of their tenures, ≈øo neere as they can, to thintent the Lorde may haue his reliefe, which is but the value of one yeeres quitrent of the Tenement holden of the ≈øaide mannours, or of either of them by Socage tenure.

10 Item, if the homage at anie of the ≈øaide Courts of either of the ≈øaide mannours, ≈øhall not knowe who is next heire or heyres to anie of the ≈øaide cu≈øtomarye Tenauntes ≈øo dying ≈øeazed, when they ≈øhall make their pre≈øentments, that then they ≈øhall make their pre≈øentment ≈øo accordingly, and then vppon the ≈øaide pre≈øentment, at the next generall Court after the Stewarde of the ≈øaide mannors or of eyther of them, or his deputie for the time being, within which the ≈øaide pre≈øentment ≈øhall ≈øo bee made, ≈øhall cau≈øe a Proclamation to be made in open court, to thintent euerie ≈øuch heyre or heyres may haue knowledge to come and take vp the Landes and tenements of his or
their aunce≈øtours, and ≈øo the Steward or his deputie, ≈øhall cau≈øe a Proclamation to bee made from generall Court to generall Court, vntill three open and publique Proclamations bee made in ful Court, at three ≈øeuerall generall courts, which generall Courts, by the ≈øaid cu≈øtome are v≈øed to bee holden commonlie one halfe yeere after another or there abouts, ≈øo that from the fir≈øt Proclamation to the la≈øt, is full neere one yeere and a halfe, which is about full two yeeres from the pre≈øentment made by the ≈øayde Homage of the dying ≈øeazed, of the ≈øayde la≈øt Tenaunt, vnto the la≈øt Proclamation, and if there ≈øhall come no heire to the ≈øaide Lands or Tenements, before the ende of the ≈øaide three Proclamations, to make his clayme, and prooue him≈øelfe to the Homage of the ≈øaide Court, in ≈øuche ≈øort as they ≈øhall allowe off, to bee the next heire of the whole blood, to the ≈øaide Tenaunte decea≈øed, or to haue title to the Lande and tenements, nor to ≈øhewe and prooue as afore≈øaid, who is or ought to be the next heire of the whole bloud to the ≈øaide Tenaunt decea≈øed, or next heire
expectant vpon anie e≈øtate determined, then the Lorde of the ≈øaide Mannours, or of either of them for the time being, ≈øhal and may after the ≈øaide three Proclamations ≈øo to bee made, ≈øeaze the Landes and Tenements, which was the ≈øayde per≈øons ≈øo dying ≈øea≈øed, who≈øe next heire or ≈øuch as ≈øhall haue title therevnto cannot bee founde, or ≈øhall not come and make his or their claime and proofe as afore≈øaide, and then to take the i≈ø≈øues and profites thereof vnto his owne v≈øe, vntill ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons come that ≈øhall prooue him or them next heire or heyres to the ≈øaide per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øo dying ≈øeazed, and if none ≈øhal come within three yeeres next after the thirde and la≈øt proclamation to bee made as afore≈øaid, that ≈øhall and can conueigh and proue him or them to bee next heire or heires of the whole bloud, or ≈øhewe and prooue who is or ought to be next heire, or to haue title, as next in remaynder or reuertion as afore≈øaide. That then the ≈øaide Landes and Tenementes bee forfayted, or ≈øhall e≈øcheate vnto the Lorde of the ≈øaide
Mannour or Mannours, for the time being, except that if the ≈øaid Lands & tenements, ≈øhall or ought immediatly to de≈øcend, remaine, reuert, or come to any woman couert, or infant, within the age of xxi. yeeres, or to any per≈øon or per≈øons not of Sane memoriae, or that ≈øhall not bee within the Realme, at the time of the death of the ≈øaid la≈øt Tenaunt dying ≈øo ≈øeazed, that then the Lorde for the tyme being, ≈øhall haue but the profites of the ≈øaide Landes and Tenementes, vntill ≈øuch per≈øons or their heires, ≈øhall come and make their claime as afore≈øaide, ≈øo the ≈øaide clayme be made within fiue yeeres by the ≈øaide woman or her heires next after the death of her ≈øaid hu≈øband, or by ≈øuch per≈øon being within age, or his heires within fiue yeeres next after he ≈øhall or ≈øhould accompli≈øh his full age of twentie one yeeres, and by the heyre of ≈øuch per≈øon of Non ≈øane memoriae, within fiue yeeres after the death of his ≈øaid aunce≈øtour, or by the ≈øaid per≈øon or his heyres that ≈øhall ≈øo be out of the Realme within fiue yeeres after he ≈øhall returne, or if hee ≈øhall not returne within fiue yeeres after his death.

11 Item, women are to haue no dowers of anie cu≈øtomarie Landes or Tenements within the Mannours afore≈øaid, nor in anie of them, nor menne to haue anie e≈øtate as Tenantes by the curte≈øie of Englande.

12 Item, if a man or woman ≈øhalbe ≈øeazed of anie cu≈øtomarie Landes or Tenementes holden of the ≈øaide Mannours, or of either of them, of an e≈øtate of inheritaunce, and ≈øhal haue i≈ø≈øue two Sonnes or three Sonnes, or more, or hauing no Sonnes, ≈øhall haue diuers Daughters, or hauing neyther Sonnes nor Daughters, ≈øhall haue diuers collaterall heires, they ≈øhall be all coheyres to their ≈øayde Father, Mother, or other Aunce≈øtour touching the ≈øaide cu≈øtomarie Landes and tenements, according to the cu≈øtome of Gauelkinde.

13 Item, if a man or woman die ≈øeazed as afore≈øaide, of any cu≈øtomarie Lands or Tenementes of anie e≈øtate of inheritaunce holden of the ≈øaide Mannours, or of anie of them, and ≈øhall haue i≈ø≈øue two or three ≈øonnes or more, whereof one or
two or more of them ≈øhalbe married, and ≈øhall haue i≈ø≈øue in the life of their father or mother, and ≈øhall die before his or their ≈øaide Father or Mother, or hauing no ≈øonnes, ≈øhall haue diuers daughters, whereof one or more ≈øhalbe married, and haue i≈ø≈øue, and die in the life of the father or mother. That then the ≈øaide i≈ø≈øue ≈øhall inherite, and bee coheire with the ≈øayde ≈øonne or ≈øonnes, or daughter, that ≈øhall ≈øuruiue his or her ≈øaide father or mother that ≈øo ≈øhall die ≈øeazed, as is afore≈øaide, whether the ≈øaide i≈ø≈øue be Male or Female, according to the cu≈øtome of Gauelkinde.

14 Item, if anie per≈øon or per≈øons, dye ≈øeazed as afore≈øaide, and ≈øhall leaue behinde him neyther ≈øonne nor daughter, then the next of his or their kinne being of whole bloud, ≈øhalbe heyre or heyres to the ≈øaide per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øo dying ≈øeazed, that is to ≈øay, his or their brother, or brothers children, or childers children, according to the cu≈øtome of Gauelkinde and ≈øo foorth, as long as anie of that i≈ø≈øue ≈øhalbe on liue, being of the whole bloud, and in default of ≈øuche i≈ø≈øue, the
Si≈øters and Si≈øters children, according to the cu≈øtome of Gauelkind, and ≈øo forth as long as anie i≈ø≈øue ≈øhalbe on liue, and being of the whole bloud, and for lacke of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, the Vnckles and their i≈ø≈øues, being of the whole bloud ≈øo long as anie i≈ø≈øue ≈øhalbe liuing. And no default of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, the Aunts and their children, ≈øo long as anie ≈øhalbe liuing of the whole bloud, & for lacke of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, the next of kinne of the whole bloud, according to the cu≈øtome of Gauelkinde.

15 Item, If anie per≈øon ≈øo dying ≈øeazed as afore≈øaide, without i≈ø≈øue of his bodie, and hauing diuers brothers of the whole bloud, whereof the one or ≈øome of them ≈øhall haue beene married, and ≈øhall haue i≈ø≈øue, and after i≈ø≈øue had, ≈øhall die before the ≈øaide brother dying ≈øeazed, as afore≈øaide. That then the i≈ø≈øues of the ≈øaide brother or brothers ≈øo dying before him that died ≈øeazed, as afore≈øaide, ≈øhall ioyne and be coheyre with the brother that ≈øuruiueth the brother that ≈øo died ≈øeazed as afore≈øaide, whether the ≈øaid i≈ø≈øue be Males or Females. But Males and Females of one venter, can not ioyne to be coheires together, ≈øo
that the cour≈øe of di≈øcentes is to be ob≈øerued by the ≈øaide cu≈øtome, according to the cu≈øtome and nature of landes in Gauelkinde.
16 Item, likewi≈øe ≈øhall the i≈ø≈øue of the daughter that ≈øhall die in the life of the Father or Mother, be coheire with the Aunt that liueth, being of the whole bloud.
17 Item, likewi≈øe ≈øhall the Vnckles, and the Vnckles brothers children, being of the whole bloud, be coheires together as afore≈øaide.

18 Item, likewi≈øe ≈øhall the Aunts, and the Aunts ≈øi≈øters children, ioyne and be coheires as afore≈øaid, and ≈øo forth of all further degrees of all collaterall heires, being of the whole bloud, which may conueigh them≈øelues to be anie Co≈øins and heires of the whole bloud to anie per≈øon or per≈øons dying ≈øeazed, of anie of the fore≈øaide cu≈øtomarie Landes or Tenements, according to the cu≈øtome of Gauelkind.

19 Item, by the cu≈øtomes of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall Mannours, euerie coppieholder of inheritaunce in fee ≈øimple, may ≈øurrender his ≈øaide coppieholde Landes and Tenements, or anie part or parcell therof vnto any per≈øon or per≈øons, and to his or their heires for euer, or to his or their heires, of his or their bodies, or any other waies intaile, or for life or liues, or yeres, or to anie per≈øon or per≈øons, and to their heires, to thintent the ≈øaide coppieholde Tenante may declare his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament vppon the ≈øame Lands and Tenements, or to anie other v≈øe or v≈øes, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee to anie corporation or corporations, or bodies politique or corporate. And euerie coppieholder intayle, for life, liues or yeeres, of anie of the ≈øaide Mannours, may in like manner by the cu≈øtomes of the ≈øaide Manuours, and of euerie of them, ≈øurrender their coppieholde Landes, or anie part thereof, according to the nature of their e≈øtates, ≈øo the ≈øame ≈øurrender be made according to the cu≈øtome concerning ≈øurrenders, as heereafter en≈øueth.
